Transform API Descriptions from/to various formats
=============================================

The `transform` endpoint allows you to convert API descriptions from/to various formats.

### Inputs

The following inputs are supported:

* `API Blueprint`
* `Swagger 1.0 - 1.2`
* `Swagger 2.0 JSON`
* `Swagger 2.0 YAML`
* `WADL - W3C 2009`
* `RAML 0.8`
* `I/O Docs - Mashery`
* `HAR 1.2`
* `Postman Collection 1.0 - 2.0`
* `APIMATIC Format`
* `Mashape`

### Outputs

The following outputs are supported:

* `API Blueprint`
* `Swagger 1.2`
* `Swagger 2.0 JSON`
* `Swagger 2.0 YAML`
* `WADL - W3C 2009`
* `RAML 0.8 - 1.0`
* `APIMATIC Format`

### Request Body

The request body is a `multipart/form-data` with a single part containing the API description in the format specified in the `format` parameter.

### Parameters

The following parameters are required:

* `format`: The format of the API description to be converted. The valid values are:
	+ `swagger10`: Swagger 1.0
	+ `swagger20`: Swagger 2.0
	+ `swaggeryaml`: Swagger 2.0 YAML
	+ `apiblueprint`: API Blueprint
	+ `wadl2009`: WADL - W3C 2009
	+ `raml`: RAML 0.8 - 1.0
	+ `apimatic`: APIMATIC Format

### Responses

The endpoint returns the converted API specification in the format specified in the `format` parameter. The following responses are possible:

* `200`: The converted API specification
* `429`: Rate-limit exceeded

### Security

The endpoint does not support any security schemes.

### External Docs

The endpoint provides a link to the API Transformer website for more information.

### Unofficial Spec

The endpoint supports an unofficial specification for the API description format.

### Request Example

Here is an example of a request to the `transform` endpoint:
```bash
POST /transform
Content-Type: multipart/form-data

--boundary
a_boundary

Content-Type: application/json

{
  "format": "swagger20",
  "url": "https://api.example.com/swagger.json"
}

--boundary
a_boundary
```
This request will convert the API specification at `https://api.example.com/swagger.json` to Swagger 2.0 JSON format and return the converted specification in the response.

Instruction:

OpenAPI 3.0.1

servers:
  - url: https://api.geodatasource.com

info:
  contact:
    x-twitter: _geodatasource
  description: GeoDataSource Location Search is a REST API that enables users to lookup for a city by using latitude and longitude coordinate. It will return the result in either JSON or XML containing the information of country, region, city, latitude, and longitude.
  title: GeoDataSource Location Search
  version: 1.0
  x-apisguru-categories: ["location"]
  x-logo:
    url: https://api.apis.guru/v2/cache/logo/https_twitter.com__geodatasource_profile_image.png
  x-origin:
    converter:
      url: https://github.com/lucybot/api-spec-converter
      version: 2.7.31
      format: openapi
      url: https://app.swaggerhub.com/apiproxy/schema/file/geodatasource/geodatasource-location-search/1.0/swagger.yaml
      version: 3.0
    x-providerName: geodatasource.com

paths:
  /city:
    get:
      description: Get City name by using latitude and longitude
      parameters:
        - in: query
          name: key
            required: true
            schema:
              type: string
        - in: query
          name: lng
            required: true
            schema:
              type: number
        - in: query
          name: lat
            required: true
            schema:
              type: number
        - in: query
          name: format
          schema:
            enum: ["json", "xml"]
            type: string
      responses:
        200:
          content:
            application/json; charset=utf-8:
              examples:
                0:
                  value: {"country":"","region":"","city":"","latitude": "", "longitude": ""}
              schema:
                type: string
      description: Get response from longitude latitude lookup

Function Calling:
===============

$ curl -X GET https://api.geodatasource.com/city?key=123&lng=123.456&lat=

* Call the `getAirport` function with the ICAO code as a path parameter.
* The function should return an object with the ICAO code, last update, name, and URL.

Example:
```json
{
  "icao_code": "EDDB",
  "last_update": "2022-01-01T00:00:00Z",
  "name": "Frankfurt Airport",
  "url": "https://www.frankfurt-airport.com"
}
```

Instruction:
================

The MailboxValidator Free Email Checker checks if a single email address is from a free email provider and returns the results in either JSON or XML format. Refer to [www.mailboxvalidator.com/api-email-freem](http://www.mailboxvalidator.com/api-email-freem) for further information.

Function Calling:
=================

```bash
curl -X GET \
  https://api.mailboxvalidator.com/v1/email/free \
  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  -H 'api-key: <YOUR_API_KEY>'
```

Note:
-------

* Replace `<YOUR_API_KEY>` with your MailboxValidator API key.
* The `Content-Type` header is set to `application/json` to indicate that the request body will be sent in JSON format.

Instruction:
============

Co-WIN Certificate API
=====================

The Co-WIN Certificate API is an API to get Co-WIN vaccination certificates. The API is designed to provide a simple and secure way to retrieve vaccination certificates.

Function Calling:
=================

To use the Co-WIN Certificate API, you can call the `/pdf/certificate` endpoint. This endpoint will return the vaccination certificate in PDF format.

Here is an example of how to call the `/pdf/certificate` endpoint:
```bash
POST /pdf/certificate
```
Request Body:
=============

The request body for the `/pdf/certificate` endpoint should contain the following information:

* `beneficiaryId`: The unique identifier of the beneficiary for whom the certificate is being requested.
* `mobile`: The mobile number of the beneficiary.

Here is an example of what the request body might look like:
```json
{
  "beneficiaryId": "1234567890",
  "mobile": "9999999999"
}
```
Security:
=========

The `/pdf/certificate` endpoint requires authentication using the `Authorization` header. The value of the `Authorization` header should be `Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN`, where `YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN` is the access token obtained from the authorization server.

Here is an example of how to include the `Authorization` header in the request:
```bash
Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN
```
Response:
=========

The `/pdf/certificate` endpoint will return the vaccination certificate in PDF format. The response will have the following structure:
```json
{
  "certificate": {
    "pdf": "base64-encoded PDF content"
  }
}
```

{
  "certificate": {
    "pdf": "MjAwOS0xMjAwMTAwMzQwMzQwMzQwMzQwMzQwMzQwMzQwMzQwM
